Idiom (Ibibio): Ebot eda ndaha ke idem esie
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause; third-person subject; reflexive structure
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone who causes their own downfall or misfortune
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from Ibibio folktales emphasizing personal responsibility
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ibibio): ɛ̀bɔ́t ɛ̀dá ndáhá kɛ́ ídɛm èsíɛ́
First Example Sentence: Ebot eda ndaha ke idem esie nte ami akpaña ima.
Second Example Sentence: Okim emi ama kpukpru ifañ, ebot eda ndaha ke idem esie.
Third Example Sentence: Eka mi akan kiet mi, ‘Ebot eda ndaha ke idem esie!’

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause; noun phrase with embedded clause
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Rumors spread quickly or reach far
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in communal communication in pre-colonial Ibibio villages
First Example Sentence: Ñwed ikpat owo ndɔk edim ke mkpọ itie emi.
Second Example Sentence: Ke ubɔñ owo, ñwed ikpat owo ndɔk edim ke usen eti.
Third Example Sentence: Nnyin akam idiọk ifañ emi, ñwed ikpat owo ndɔk edim.

Idiom (Ibibio): Okim ke akwa iso eti ifañ
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed expression; prepositional phrase with noun complement
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A wise person speaks with reason and clarity
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Ancient Ibibio councils where elders’ words were revered
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ibibio): òkìm ké ákʷá ísɔ́ ɛ́tí ífáɲ
First Example Sentence: Okim ke akwa iso eti ifañ ke nsinsi udim.
Second Example Sentence: Ami amaña ke okim emi, okim ke akwa iso eti ifañ.
Third Example Sentence: Ete mi eda nte, okim ke akwa iso eti ifañ.

Idiom (Ibibio): Akpaña ifañ ke mbak iso ibañ
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Clause with prepositional phrase; figurative construction
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Speaking out of turn or revealing secrets
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ibibio): àkpáɲá ífáɲ ké mbák ísɔ́ íbáɲ
First Example Sentence: Edi idiọk, akpaña ifañ ke mbak iso ibañ.
Second Example Sentence: Eka mi akpọñ mi, ‘Nyin akpaña ifañ ke mbak iso ibañ!’
Third Example Sentence: Ufan mi edi ndɔŋ, akpaña ifañ ke mbak iso ibañ.

Idiom (Ibibio): Anwan akpaña ubok ekom ke ima
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A woman shows affection through kind acts
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: A kind woman expresses love through her deeds
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: From folk songs celebrating feminine virtue
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ibibio): ànwán ákpaɲá úbɔ́k ɛ̀kɔ́m ké ímá
First Example Sentence: Anwan akpaña ubok ekom ke ima ke udim emi.
Second Example Sentence: Ami eti, anwan akpaña ubok ekom ke ima.
Third Example Sentence: Eka mi edi eti nte anwan akpaña ubok ekom ke ima.

Idiom (Ibibio): Ñkpɔ emi edi utom, idiọk ukotke
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ibibio): ŋkpɔ́ émì édí útɔ́m ídíɔ́k ùkɔ̀tkɛ́
First Example Sentence: Ñkpɔ emi edi utom, idiọk ukotke, nte eka mi akan.
Second Example Sentence: Ami idiọk kpukpru ke utom mi, idiọk ukotke.
Third Example Sentence: Ñkpɔ emi edi utom, idiọk ukotke nte mmọ.

Idiom (Ibibio): Edi eti ke akam ke okim
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Ibibio moral philosophy linking virtue and wisdom
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ibibio): édí étí ké ákám ké òkìm
First Example Sentence: Edi eti ke akam ke okim ke idaha eti.
Second Example Sentence: Edi eti ke akam ke okim, ami idiọk nte ete mi.
Third Example Sentence: Okim ke akwa iso eti ifañ, edi eti ke akam ke okim.

Idiom (Ibibio): Owo edi ñkpɔ ubok, idiọk ama kiet
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone who has power but uses it carelessly
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Proverb used to caution against abuse of power
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ibibio): ɔ́wɔ̀ édí ŋkpɔ́ úbɔ́k ídíɔ́k ámá kíɛ̀t
First Example Sentence: Owo edi ñkpɔ ubok, idiọk ama kiet ke leadership.
Second Example Sentence: Ete mi emi idiọk ama kiet, owo edi ñkpɔ ubok.
Third Example Sentence: Nnyin akan ete, owo edi ñkpɔ ubok, idiọk ama kiet.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Ibibio wisdom on life cycles

Third Example Sentence: Ke isañ emi, ebot kiet, ifañ ekpri.
